VDR overexpression was significantly associated with KRAS mutation (odds ratio, 1.55; 95% confidence interval, 1.11-2.16) and PIK3CA mutation (odds ratio, 2.17; 95% confidence interval, 1.36-3.47), both of which persisted in multivariate logistic regression analysis.

VDR was not independently associated with body mass index, family history of colorectal cancer, tumor location (colon versus rectum), stage, tumor grade, signet ring cells, CIMP, MSI, LINE-1 hypomethylation, BRAF, p53, p21, beta-catenin, or cyclooxygenase-2.
VDR expression was not significantly related with patient survival, prognosis, or clinical outcome.
In conclusion, VDR overexpression in colorectal cancer is independently associated with PIK3CA and KRAS mutations.
Our data support potential interactions between the VDR, RAS-MAPK and PI3K-AKT pathways, and possible influence by KRAS or PIK3CA mutation on therapy or chemoprevention targeting VDR.
Cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis protects liver sinusoidal endothelial cells in acute liver injured mice.

Cultured mycelium [MS] Cordyceps sinensis [ME] ([MS] CMCS [ME]) was widely used for a variety of diseases including liver injury, the current study aims to investigate the protective effects of [MS] CMCS [ME] on liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) in acute injury liver and related action mechanisms.
The mice were injected intraperitoneally with [MS] lipopolysaccharide [ME] ([MS] LPS [ME]) and [MS] D-galactosamine [ME] ([MS] D-GalN [ME]).
39 male BABL/c mice were randomly divided into four groups: normal control, model control, [MS] CMCS [ME] treatment and [MS] 1,10-phenanthroline [ME] treatment groups.
The Serum liver function parameters including alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels were assayed with the commercial kit.
The inflammation and scaffold structure in liver were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and [MS] silver [ME] staining respectively.
The LSECs and sub-endothelial basement membrane were observed with the scanning and transmission electronic microscope.
The protein expressions of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) in liver were analyzed with Western blotting.
Expression of von Willebrand factor (vWF) was investigated with immunofluorescence staining.

The [MS] lipid [ME] peroxidation indicators including [MS] antisuperoxideanion [ME] ([MS] ASAFR [ME]), [MS] hydroxyl free radical [ME] ([MS] .OH [ME]), superoxide dismutase (SOD), [MS] malondialdehyde [ME] and glutathione S-transferase (GST) were determined with kits, and matrix metalloproteinase-2 and 9 (MMP-2/9) activities in liver were analyzed with gelatin zymography and in situ fluorescent zymography respectively.
The model mice had much higher serum levels of ALT and AST than the normal mice.

Compared to that in the normal control, more severe liver inflammation and hepatocyte apoptosis, worse hepatic [MS] lipid [ME] peroxidation demonstrated by the increased ASAFR, [MS] .OH [ME] and [MS] MDA [ME], but decreased SOD and GST, increased MMP-2/9 activities and VCAM-1, ICAM-1 and vWF expressions, which revealed obvious LSEC injury and scaffold structure broken, were shown in the model control.

Compared with the model group, [MS] CMCS [ME] and [MS] 1,10-phenanthroline [ME] significantly improved serum ALT/AST, attenuated hepatic inflammation and improved peroxidative injury in liver, decreased MMP-2/9 activities in liver tissue, improved integration of scaffold structure, and decreased protein expression of VCAM-1 and ICAM-1.
CMCS could protect LSECs from injury and maintain the microvasculature integration in acute injured liver of mice induced by [MS] LPS [ME]/[MS] D-GalN. [ME]
Its action mechanism was associated with the down-regulation of MMP-2/9 activities and inhibition of peroxidation in injured liver.
A Type 2 Diabetes-Associated Functional Regulatory Variant in a Pancreatic Islet Enhancer at the ADCY5 Locus.
Molecular mechanisms remain unknown for most type 2 diabetes genome-wide association study identified loci.
Variants associated with type 2 diabetes and fasting [MS] glucose [ME] levels reside in introns of ADCY5, a gene that encodes adenylate cyclase 5.
Adenylate cyclase 5 catalyzes the production of [MS] cyclic AMP [ME], which is a second messenger molecule involved in cell signaling and pancreatic b-cell insulin secretion.

We demonstrated that type 2 diabetes risk alleles are associated with decreased ADCY5 expression in human islets and examined candidate variants for regulatory function. rs11708067 overlaps a predicted enhancer region in pancreatic islets.

The type 2 diabetes risk rs11708067-A allele showed fewer H3K27ac ChIP-seq reads in human islets, lower transcriptional activity in reporter assays in rodent b-cells (rat 832/13 and mouse MIN6), and increased nuclear protein binding compared with the rs11708067-G allele.

Homozygous deletion of the orthologous enhancer region in 832/13 cells resulted in a 64% reduction in expression level of Adcy5, but not adjacent gene Sec22a, and a 39% reduction in insulin secretion.
Together, these data suggest that rs11708067-A risk allele contributes to type 2 diabetes by disrupting an islet enhancer, which results in reduced ADCY5 expression and impaired insulin secretion.
Homozygously deleted gene DACH1 regulates tumor-initiating activity of glioma cells.
Loss or reduction in function of tumor suppressor genes contributes to tumorigenesis.

Here, by allelic DNA copy number analysis using single-nucleotide polymorphism genotyping array and mass spectrometry, we report homozygous deletion in glioblastoma multiformes at chromosome 13q21, where DACH1 gene is located.
We found decreased cell proliferation of a series of glioma cell lines by forced expression of DACH1.
We then generated U87TR-Da glioma cells, where DACH1 expression could be activated by exposure of the cells to [MS] doxycycline [ME].

Both ex vivo cellular proliferation and in vivo growth of s.c. transplanted tumors in mice are reduced in U87TR-Da cells with DACH1 expression (U87-DACH1-high), compared with DACH1-nonexpressing U87TR-Da cells (U87-DACH1-low).
U87-DACH1-low cells form spheroids with CD133 and Nestin expression in serum-free medium but U87-DACH1-high cells do not.
Compared with spheroid-forming U87-DACH1-low cells, adherent U87-DACH1-high cells display lower tumorigenicity, indicating DACH1 decreases the number of tumor-initiating cells.

Gene expression analysis and chromatin immunoprecipitation assay reveal that fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2/bFGF) is transcriptionally repressed by DACH1, especially in cells cultured in serum-free medium.

Exogenous bFGF rescues spheroid-forming activity and tumorigenicity of the U87-DACH1-high cells, suggesting that loss of DACH1 increases the number of tumor-initiating cells through transcriptional activation of bFGF.
These results illustrate that DACH1 is a distinctive tumor suppressor, which does not only suppress growth of tumor cells but also regulates bFGF-mediated tumor-initiating activity of glioma cells.
Definition and management of anemia in patients infected with hepatitis C virus.
Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) can progress to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage liver disease.
The current best treatment for HCV infection is combination therapy with [MS] pegylated interferon [ME] and [MS] ribavirin [ME].
Although this regimen produces sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in approximately 50% of patients, it can be associated with a potentially dose-limiting hemolytic anemia.

Hemoglobin concentrations decrease mainly as a result of [MS] ribavirin [ME]-induced hemolysis, and this anemia can be problematic in patients with HCV infection, especially those who have comorbid renal or cardiovascular disorders.
In general, anemia can increase the risk of morbidity and mortality, and may have negative effects on cerebral function and quality of life.
Although [MS] ribavirin [ME]-associated anemia can be reversed by dose reduction or discontinuation, this approach compromises outcomes by significantly decreasing SVR rates.
Recombinant human erythropoietin has been used to manage [MS] ribavirin [ME]-associated anemia but has other potential disadvantages.

[MS] Viramidine [ME], a liver-targeting prodrug of [MS] ribavirin [ME], has the potential to maintain the virologic efficacy of [MS] ribavirin [ME] while decreasing the risk of hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hepatitis C.
Assessment of a new non-invasive index of cardiac performance for detection of [MS] dobutamine [ME]-induced myocardial ischemia.
BACKGROUND: Electrocardiography has a very low sensitivity in detecting [MS] dobutamine [ME]-induced myocardial ischemia.

OBJECTIVES: To assess the added diagnostic value of a new cardiac performance index (dP/dtejc) measurement, based on brachial artery flow changes, as compared to standard 12-lead ECG, for detecting [MS] dobutamine [ME]-induced myocardial ischemia, using [MS] Tc99m-Sestamibi [ME] single-photon emission computed tomography as the gold standard of comparison to assess the presence or absence of ischemia.
METHODS: The study group comprised 40 patients undergoing [MS] Sestamibi [ME]-SPECT/[MS] dobutamine [ME] stress test.
Simultaneous measurements of ECG and brachial artery dP/dtejc were performed at each [MS] dobutamine [ME] level.
In 19 of the 40 patients perfusion defects compatible with ischemia were detected on SPECT.

The increase in dP/dtejc during infusion of [MS] dobutamine [ME] in this group was severely impaired as compared to the non-ischemic group. dP/dtejc outcome was combined with the ECG results, giving an ECG-enhanced value, and compared to ECG alone.

RESULTS: The sensitivity improved dramatically from 16% to 79%, positive predictive value increased from 60% to 68% and negative predictive value from 54% to 78%, and specificity decreased from 90% to 67%.

CONCLUSIONS: If ECG alone is used for specificity, the combination with dP/dtejc improved the sensitivity of the test and could be a cost-savings alternative to cardiac imaging or perfusion studies to detect myocardial ischemia, especially in patients unable to exercise.
Male 11b-HSD1 Knockout Mice Fed Trans-Fats and [MS] Fructose [ME] Are Not Protected From Metabolic Syndrome or Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) defines a spectrum of conditions from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and cirrhosis and is regarded as the hepatic manifestation of the metabolic syndrome.
[MS] Glucocorticoids [ME] can promote steatosis by stimulating lipolysis within adipose tissue, [MS] free fatty acid [ME] delivery to liver and hepatic de novo lipogenesis.
[MS] Glucocorticoids [ME] can be reactivated in liver through 11b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (11b-HSD1) enzyme activity.
Inhibition of 11b-HSD1 has been suggested as a potential treatment for NAFLD.

To test this, male mice with global (11b-HSD1 knockout [KO]) and liver-specific (LKO) 11b-HSD1 loss of function were fed the American Lifestyle Induced Obesity Syndrome (ALIOS) diet, known to recapitulate the spectrum of NAFLD, and metabolic and liver phenotypes assessed.
Body weight, muscle and adipose tissue masses, and parameters of [MS] glucose [ME] homeostasis showed that 11b-HSD1KO and LKO mice were not protected from systemic metabolic disease.
Evaluation of hepatic histology, [MS] triglyceride [ME] content, and blinded NAFLD activity score assessment indicated that levels of steatosis were similar between 11b-HSD1KO, LKO, and control mice.
Unexpectedly, histological analysis revealed significantly increased levels of immune foci present in livers of 11b-HSD1KO but not LKO or control mice, suggestive of a transition to NASH.
This was endorsed by elevated hepatic expression of key immune cell and inflammatory markers.
These data indicate that 11b-HSD1-deficient mice are not protected from metabolic disease or hepatosteatosis in the face of a NAFLD-inducing diet.
However, global deficiency of 11b-HSD1 did increase markers of hepatic inflammation and suggests a critical role for 11b-HSD1 in restraining the transition to NASH.
Pheochromocytoma unmasked by [MS] amisulpride [ME] and [MS] tiapride [ME].
OBJECTIVE: To describe the unmasking of pheochromocytoma in a patient treated with [MS] amisulpride [ME] and [MS] tiapride [ME].
CASE SUMMARY: A 42-year-old white man developed acute hypertension with severe headache and vomiting 2 hours after the first doses of [MS] amisulpride [ME] 100 mg and [MS] tiapride [ME] 100 mg.
Both drugs were immediately discontinued, and the patient recovered after subsequent [MS] nicardipine [ME] and [MS] verapamil [ME] treatment.
Abdominal ultrasound showed an adrenal mass, and postoperative histologic examination confirmed the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.
DISCUSSION: Drug-induced symptoms of pheochromocytoma are often associated with the use of substituted [MS] benzamide [ME] drugs, but the underlying mechanism is unknown.
In our case, use of the Naranjo probability scale indicated a possible relationship between the hypertensive crisis and [MS] amisulpride [ME] and [MS] tiapride [ME] therapy.
CONCLUSIONS: As of March 24, 2005, this is the first reported case of [MS] amisulpride [ME]- and [MS] tiapride [ME]-induced hypertensive crisis in a patient with pheochromocytoma.
Physicians and other healthcare professionals should be aware of this potential adverse effect of [MS] tiapride [ME] and [MS] amisulpride [ME].
[MS] Phenylephrine [ME] but not [MS] ephedrine [ME] reduces frontal lobe oxygenation following anesthesia-induced hypotension.
BACKGROUND: Vasopressor agents are used to correct anesthesia-induced hypotension.
We describe the effect of [MS] phenylephrine [ME] and [MS] ephedrine [ME] on frontal lobe oxygenation (S(c)[MS] O(2) [ME]) following anesthesia-induced hypotension.

METHODS: Following induction of anesthesia by [MS] fentanyl [ME] (0.15 mg kg(-1)) and [MS] propofol [ME] (2.0 mg kg(-1)), 13 patients received [MS] phenylephrine [ME] (0.1 mg iv) and 12 patients received [MS] ephedrine [ME] (10 mg iv) to restore mean arterial pressure (MAP).
Heart rate (HR), MAP, stroke volume (SV), cardiac output (CO), and frontal lobe oxygenation (S(c)[MS] O(2) [ME]) were registered.
RESULTS: Induction of anesthesia was followed by a decrease in MAP, HR, SV, and CO concomitant with an elevation in S(c)O [MS] (2 [ME]).
After administration of [MS] phenylephrine [ME], MAP increased (51 +/- 12 to 81 +/- 13 mmHg; P < 0.001; mean +/- SD).
However, a 14% (from 70 +/- 8% to 60 +/- 7%) reduction in S(c)[MS] O(2) [ME] (P < 0.05) followed with no change in CO (3.7 +/- 1.1 to 3.4 +/- 0.9 l min(-1)).
The administration of [MS] ephedrine [ME] led to a similar increase in MAP (53 +/- 9 to 79 +/- 8 mmHg; P < 0.001), restored CO (3.2 +/- 1.2 to 5.0 +/- 1.3 l min(-1)), and preserved S(c)O(2).

CONCLUSIONS: The utilization of [MS] phenylephrine [ME] to correct hypotension induced by anesthesia has a negative impact on S(c)[MS] O(2 [ME]) while [MS] ephedrine [ME] maintains frontal lobe oxygenation potentially related to an increase in CO.
Complete atrioventricular block secondary to [MS] lithium [ME] therapy.
Sinus node dysfunction has been reported most frequently among the adverse cardiovascular effects of [MS] lithium [ME].
In the present case, complete atrioventricular (AV) block with syncopal attacks developed secondary to [MS] lithium [ME] therapy, necessitating permanent pacemaker implantation.
Serum [MS] lithium [ME] levels remained under or within the therapeutic range during the syncopal attacks.
[MS] Lithium [ME] should be used with extreme caution, especially in patients with mild disturbance of AV conduction.
[MS] Organophosphate [ME]-induced convulsions and prevention of neuropathological damages.

Such [MS] organophosphorus [ME] ([MS] OP [ME]) compounds as [MS] diisopropylfluorophosphate [ME] ([MS] DFP [ME]), [MS] sarin [ME] and [MS] soman [ME] are potent inhibitors of acetylcholinesterases (AChEs) and butyrylcholinesterases (BChEs).
The acute toxicity of [MS] OPs [ME] is the result of their irreversible binding with AChEs in the central nervous system (CNS), which elevates [MS] acetylcholine [ME] ([MS] ACh [ME]) levels.
The protective action of subcutaneously (SC) administered antidotes or their combinations in [MS] DFP [ME] (2.0 mg/kg BW) intoxication was studied in 9-10-weeks-old Han-Wistar male rats.

The rats received AChE reactivator [MS] pralidoxime-2-chloride [ME] ([MS] 2PAM [ME]) (30.0 mg/kg BW), anticonvulsant [MS] diazepam [ME] (2.0 mg/kg BW), A(1)-adenosine receptor agonist [MS] N(6)-cyclopentyl adenosine [ME] ([MS] CPA [ME]) (2.0 mg/kg BW), NMDA-receptor antagonist [MS] dizocilpine maleate [ME] ([MS] +-MK801 hydrogen maleate [ME]) (2.0 mg/kg BW) or their combinations with cholinolytic drug [MS] atropine sulfate [ME] (50.0 mg/kg BW) immediately or 30 min after the single SC injection of [MS] DFP [ME].
The control rats received [MS] atropine sulfate [ME], but also saline and [MS] olive oil [ME] instead of other antidotes and [MS] DFP [ME], respectively.
All rats were terminated either 24 h or 3 weeks after the [MS] DFP [ME] injection.
The rats treated with [MS] DFP [ME]-[MS] atropine [ME] showed severe typical [MS] OP [ME]-induced toxicity signs.

When [MS] CPA [ME], [MS] diazepam [ME] or [MS] 2PAM [ME] was given immediately after [MS] DFP [ME]-[MS] atropine [ME], these treatments prevented, delayed or shortened the occurrence of serious signs of poisoning.
[MS] Atropine [ME]-[MS] MK801 [ME] did not offer any additional protection against [MS] DFP [ME] toxicity.

In conclusion, [MS] CPA [ME], [MS] diazepam [ME] and [MS] 2PAM [ME] in combination with [MS] atropine [ME] prevented the occurrence of serious signs of poisoning and thus reduced the toxicity of [MS] DFP [ME] in rat.

The activation of spinal N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors may contribute to degeneration of spinal motor neurons induced by neuraxial [MS] morphine [ME] after a noninjurious interval of spinal cord ischemia.

We investigated the relationship between the degeneration of spinal motor neurons and activation of N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors after neuraxial [MS] morphine [ME] following a noninjurious interval of aortic occlusion in rats.
Spinal cord ischemia was induced by aortic occlusion for 6 min with a balloon catheter.

In a microdialysis study, 10 muL of saline (group C; n = 8) or 30 mug of [MS] morphine [ME] (group M; n = 8) was injected intrathecally (IT) 0.5 h after reflow, and 30 mug of [MS] morphine [ME] (group SM; n = 8) or 10 muL of saline (group SC; n = 8) was injected IT 0.5 h after sham operation.
Microdialysis samples were collected preischemia, before IT injection, and at 2, 4, 8, 24, and 48 h of reperfusion (after IT injection).
Second, we investigated the effect of IT [MS] MK-801 [ME] (30 mug) on the histopathologic changes in the spinal cord after [MS] morphine [ME]-induced spastic paraparesis.
After IT [MS] morphine [ME], the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) [MS] glutamate [ME] concentration was increased in group M relative to both baseline and group C (P < 0.05).
This increase persisted for 8 hrs.
IT [MS] MK-801 [ME] significantly reduced the number of dark-stained alpha-motoneurons after [MS] morphine [ME]-induced spastic paraparesis compared with the saline group.
These data indicate that IT [MS] morphine [ME] induces spastic paraparesis with a concomitant increase in CSF [MS] glutamate [ME], which is involved in NMDA receptor activation.
We suggest that opioids may be neurotoxic in the setting of spinal cord ischemia via NMDA receptor activation.
Growth-associated protein 43 expression in hippocampal molecular layer of chronic epileptic rats treated with [MS] cycloheximide [ME].
PURPOSE: GAP43 has been thought to be linked with mossy fiber sprouting (MFS) in various experimental models of epilepsy.

To investigate how GAP43 expression (GAP43-ir) correlates with MFS, we assessed the intensity (densitometry) and extension (width) of GAP43-ir in the inner molecular layer of the dentate gyrus (IML) of rats subject to status epilepticus induced by [MS] pilocarpine [ME] ([MS] Pilo [ME]), previously injected or not with [MS] cycloheximide [ME] ([MS] CHX [ME]), which has been shown to inhibit MFS.
METHODS: [MS] CHX [ME] was injected before the [MS] Pilo [ME] injection in adult Wistar rats.
The [MS] Pilo [ME] group was injected with the same drugs, except for [MS] CHX [ME].
Animals were killed between 30 and 60 days later, and brain sections were processed for GAP43 immunohistochemistry.
RESULTS: Densitometry showed no significant difference regarding GAP43-ir in the IML between [MS] Pilo [ME], [MS] CHX [ME]+[MS] Pilo [ME], and control groups.

However, the results of the width of the GAP43-ir band in the IML showed that [MS] CHX [ME]+[MS] Pilo [ME] and control animals had a significantly larger band (p = 0.03) as compared with that in the [MS] Pilo [ME] group.

CONCLUSIONS: Our current finding that animals in the [MS] CHX [ME]+[MS] Pilo [ME] group have a GAP43-ir band in the IML, similar to that of controls, reinforces prior data on the blockade of MFS in these animals.

The change in GAP43-ir present in [MS] Pilo [ME]-treated animals was a thinning of the band to a very narrow layer just above the granule cell layer that is likely to be associated with the loss of hilar cell projections that express GAP-43.
[MS] Daidzein [ME] activates choline acetyltransferase from MC-IXC cells and improves drug-induced amnesia.

The choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) activator, which enhances cholinergic transmission via an augmentation of the enzymatic production of [MS] acetylcholine [ME] ([MS] ACh [ME]), is an important factor in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD).
Methanolic extracts from Pueraria thunbergiana exhibited an activation effect (46%) on ChAT in vitro.
Via the sequential isolation of Pueraria thunbergiana, the active component was ultimately identified as [MS] daidzein [ME] ([MS] 4',7-dihydroxy-isoflavone [ME]).
In order to investigate the effects of [MS] daidzein [ME] from Pueraria thunbergiana on [MS] scopolamine [ME]-induced impairments of learning and memory, we conducted a series of in vivo tests.
Administration of [MS] daidzein [ME] (4.5 mg/kg body weight) to mice was shown significantly to reverse [MS] scopolamine [ME]-induced amnesia, according to the results of a Y-maze test.
Injections of [MS] scopolamine [ME] into mice resulted in impaired performance on Y-maze tests (a 37% decreases in alternation behavior).

By way of contrast, mice treated with [MS] daidzein [ME] prior to the [MS] scopolamine [ME] injections were noticeably protected from this performance impairment (an approximately 12%-21% decrease in alternation behavior).
These results indicate that [MS] daidzein [ME] might play a role in [MS] acetylcholine [ME] biosynthesis as a ChAT activator, and that it also ameliorates [MS] scopolamine [ME]-induced amnesia.
Effect of [MS] alpha-tocopherol [ME] and [MS] deferoxamine [ME] on [MS] methamphetamine [ME]-induced neurotoxicity.
[MS] Methamphetamine [ME] ([MS] MA [ME])-induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity is believed to be associated with the increased formation of free radicals.

This study examined the effect of [MS] alpha-tocopherol [ME] ([MS] alpha-TC [ME]), a scavenger of reactive [MS] oxygen species [ME], and [MS] deferoxamine [ME] ([MS] DFO [ME]), an [MS] iron [ME] chelator, on the [MS] MA [ME]-induced neurotoxicity.
Male rats were treated with [MS] MA [ME] (10 mg/kg, every 2 h for four injections).

The rat received either [MS] alpha-TC [ME] (20 mg/kg) intraperitoneally for 3 days and 30 min prior to [MS] MA [ME] administration or [MS] DFO [ME] (50 mg/kg) subcutaneously 30 min before [MS] MA [ME] administration.

The concentrations of [MS] dopamine [ME] ([MS] DA [ME]), [MS] serotonin [ME] and their metabolites decreased significantly after [MS] MA [ME] administration, which was inhibited by the [MS] alpha-TC [ME] and [MS] DFO [ME] pretreatment. [MS] alpha-TC [ME] and [MS] DFO [ME] attenuated the [MS] MA [ME]-induced hyperthermia as well as the alterations in the locomotor activity.
The level of [MS] lipid [ME] peroxidation was higher and the reduced [MS] glutathione [ME] concentration was lower in the [MS] MA [ME]-treated rats.
These changes were significantly attenuated by [MS] alpha-TC [ME] and [MS] DFO [ME].
This suggests that [MS] alpha-TC [ME] and [MS] DFO [ME] ameliorate the [MS] MA [ME]-induced neuronal damage by decreasing the level of oxidative stress.
Cardiac Angiography in Renally Impaired Patients (CARE) study: a randomized double-blind trial of [MS] contrast [ME]-induced nephropathy in patients with chronic kidney disease.

BACKGROUND: No direct comparisons exist of the renal tolerability of the low-osmolality contrast medium [MS] iopamidol [ME] with that of the iso-osmolality contrast medium [MS] iodixanol [ME] in high-risk patients.

METHODS AND RESULTS: The present study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind comparison of [MS] iopamidol [ME] and [MS] iodixanol [ME] in patients with chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate, 20 to 59 mL/min) who underwent cardiac angiography or percutaneous coronary interventions.
Serum [MS] creatinine [ME] (SCr) levels and estimated glomerular filtration rate were assessed at baseline and 2 to 5 days after receiving medications.
The primary outcome was a postdose SCr increase > or = 0.5 mg/dL (44.2 micromol/L) over baseline.
Secondary outcomes were a postdose SCr increase > or = 25%, a postdose estimated glomerular filtration rate decrease of > or = 25%, and the mean peak change in SCr.

In 414 patients, [MS] contrast [ME] volume, presence of diabetes mellitus, use of [MS] N-acetylcysteine [ME], mean baseline SCr, and estimated glomerular filtration rate were comparable in the 2 groups.

SCr increases > or = 0.5 mg/dL occurred in 4.4% (9 of 204 patients) after [MS] iopamidol [ME] and 6.7% (14 of 210 patients) after [MS] iodixanol [ME] (P=0.39), whereas rates of SCr increases > or = 25% were 9.8% and 12.4%, respectively (P=0.44).

In patients with diabetes, SCr increases > or = 0.5 mg/dL were 5.1% (4 of 78 patients) with [MS] iopamidol [ME] and 13.0% (12 of 92 patients) with [MS] iodixanol [ME] (P=0.11), whereas SCr increases > or = 25% were 10.3% and 15.2%, respectively (P=0.37).

Mean post-SCr increases were significantly less with [MS] iopamidol [ME] (all patients: 0.07 versus 0.12 mg/dL, 6.2 versus 10.6 micromol/L, P=0.03; patients with diabetes: 0.07 versus 0.16 mg/dL, 6.2 versus 14.1 micromol/L, P=0.01).

CONCLUSIONS: The rate of [MS] contrast [ME]-induced nephropathy, defined by multiple end points, is not statistically different after the intraarterial administration of [MS] iopamidol [ME] or [MS] iodixanol [ME] to high-risk patients, with or without diabetes mellitus.
Any true difference between the agents is small and not likely to be clinically significant.
[MS] Estrogen [ME] prevents [MS] cholesteryl ester [ME] accumulation in macrophages induced by the HIV protease inhibitor [MS] ritonavir [ME].
Individuals with HIV can now live long lives with drug therapy that often includes protease inhibitors such as [MS] ritonavir [ME].
Many patients, however, develop negative long-term side effects such as premature atherosclerosis.
We have previously demonstrated that [MS] ritonavir [ME] treatment increases atherosclerotic lesion formation in male mice to a greater extent than in female mice.
Furthermore, peripheral blood monocytes isolated from [MS] ritonavir [ME]-treated females had less [MS] cholesteryl ester [ME] accumulation.

In the present study, we have investigated the molecular mechanisms by which female hormones influence [MS] cholesterol [ME] metabolism in macrophages in response to the HIV protease inhibitor [MS] ritonavir [ME].
We have utilized the human monocyte cell line, THP-1 as a model to address this question.

Briefly, cells were differentiated for 72 h with 100 nM [MS] PMA [ME] to obtain a macrophage-like phenotype in the presence or absence of 1 nM [MS] 17beta-estradiol [ME] ([MS] E2 [ME]), 100 nM [MS] progesterone [ME] or vehicle (0.01% [MS] ethanol [ME]).
Cells were then treated with 30 ng/ml [MS] ritonavir [ME] or vehicle in the presence of aggregated [MS] LDL [ME] for 24 h. Cell extracts were harvested, and lipid or total RNA was isolated.
E2 decreased the accumulation of [MS] cholesteryl esters [ME] in macrophages following [MS] ritonavir [ME] treatment.
[MS] Ritonavir [ME] increased the expression of the scavenger receptor, CD36 mRNA, responsible for the uptake of [MS] LDL [ME].
Additionally, [MS] ritonavir [ME] treatment selectively increased the relative levels of PPARgamma mRNA, a transcription factor responsible for the regulation of CD36 mRNA expression.
Treatment with [MS] E2 [ME], however, failed to prevent these increases at the mRNA level.
[MS] E2 [ME] did, however, significantly suppress CD36 protein levels as measured by fluorescent immunocytochemistry.

This data suggests that [MS] E2 [ME] modifies the expression of CD36 at the level of protein expression in monocyte-derived macrophages resulting in reduced [MS] cholesteryl ester [ME] accumulation following [MS] ritonavir [ME] treatment.
Clinical comparison of cardiorespiratory effects during unilateral and conventional spinal anaesthesia.
BACKGROUND: Spinal anaesthesia is widely employed in clinical practice but has the main drawback of post-spinal block hypotension.
Efforts must therefore continue to be made to obviate this setback OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the cardiovascular and respiratory changes during unilateral and conventional spinal anaesthesia.
METHODS: With ethical approval, we studied 74 American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA), physical status class 1 and 2 patients scheduled for elective unilateral lower limb surgery.
Patients were randomly allocated into one of two groups: lateral and conventional spinal anaesthesia groups.
In the lateral position with operative side down, patients recived 10 mg (2mls) of 0.5% hyperbaric [MS] bupivacaine [ME] through a 25-gauge spinal needle.

Patients in the unilateral group were maintained in the lateral position for 15 minutes following spinal injection while those in the conventional group were turned supine immediately after injection.
Blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate and [MS] oxygen [ME] saturation were monitored over 1 hour.

RESULTS: Three patients (8.1%) in the unilateral group and 5 (13.5%) in the conventional group developed hypotension, P= 0.71. Four (10.8%) patients in the conventional group and 1 (2.7%) in the unilateral group, P= 0.17 required [MS] epinephrine [ME] infusion to treat hypotension.
Patients in the conventional group had statistically significant greater fall in the systolic blood pressures at 15, 30 and 45 minutes when compared to the baseline (P= 0.003, 0.001 and 0.004).
The mean respiratory rate and [MS] oxygen [ME] saturations in the two groups were similar.
CONCLUSION: Compared to conventional spinal anaesthesia, unilateral spinal anaesthesia was associated with fewer cardiovascular perturbations.
Also, the type of spinal block instituted affected neither the respiratory rate nor the arterial [MS] oxygen [ME] saturation.
Acute effects of [MS] N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea [ME] on hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters in [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-induced seizure in rats.

The present study aimed to investigate the anticonvulsant activity as well as the effects on the level of hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters ([MS] glutamate [ME], [MS] aspartate [ME], [MS] glycine [ME] and [MS] GABA [ME]) of [MS] N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea [ME] ([MS] VPU [ME]) in comparison to its parent compound, [MS] valproic acid [ME] ([MS] VPA [ME]).

[MS] VPU [ME] was more potent than [MS] VPA [ME], exhibiting the median effective dose (ED(50)) of 49 mg/kg in protecting rats against [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-induced seizure whereas the corresponding value for [MS] VPA [ME] was 322 mg/kg.

In vivo microdialysis demonstrated that an intraperitoneal administration of [MS] pilocarpine [ME] induced a pronounced increment of hippocampal [MS] glutamate [ME] and [MS] aspartate [ME] whereas no significant change was observed on the level of [MS] glycine [ME] and [MS] GABA [ME].

Pretreatment with either [MS] VPU [ME] (50 and 100 mg/kg) or [MS] VPA [ME] (300 and 600 mg/kg) completely abolished [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-evoked increases in extracellular [MS] glutamate [ME] and [MS] aspartate [ME].

In addition, a statistically significant reduction was also observed on the level of [MS] GABA [ME] and [MS] glycine [ME] but less than a drastic reduction of [MS] glutamate [ME] and [MS] aspartate [ME] level.

Based on the finding that [MS] VPU [ME] and [MS] VPA [ME] could protect the animals against [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-induced seizure it is suggested that the reduction of inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitters was comparatively minor and offset by a pronounced reduction of [MS] glutamate [ME] and [MS] aspartate [ME].

Therefore, like [MS] VPA [ME], the finding that [MS] VPU [ME] could drastically reduce [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-induced increases in [MS] glutamate [ME] and [MS] aspartate [ME] should account, at least partly, for its anticonvulsant activity observed in [MS] pilocarpine [ME]-induced seizure in experimental animals.
Some other mechanism than those being reported herein should be further investigated.
Delirium in a patient with toxic [MS] flecainide [ME] plasma concentrations: the role of a pharmacokinetic drug interaction with [MS] paroxetine [ME].
OBJECTIVE: To describe a case of [MS] flecainide [ME]-induced delirium associated with a pharmacokinetic drug interaction with [MS] paroxetine [ME].
CASE SUMMARY: A 69-year-old white female presented to the emergency department with a history of confusion and paranoia over the past several days.

On admission the patient was taking [MS] carvedilol [ME] 12 mg twice daily, [MS] warfarin [ME] 2 mg/day, [MS] folic acid [ME] 1 mg/day, [MS] levothyroxine [ME] 100 microg/day, [MS] pantoprazole [ME] 40 mg/day, [MS] paroxetine [ME] 40 mg/day, and [MS] flecainide [ME] 100 mg twice daily.
[MS] Flecainide [ME] had been started 2 weeks prior for atrial fibrillation.
Laboratory test findings on admission were notable only for a [MS] flecainide [ME] plasma concentration of 1360 microg/L (reference range 200-1000).
A metabolic drug interaction between [MS] flecainide [ME] and [MS] paroxetine [ME], which the patient had been taking for more than 5 years, was considered.
[MS] Paroxetine [ME] was discontinued and the dose of [MS] flecainide [ME] was reduced to 50 mg twice daily.
Her delirium resolved 3 days later.
DISCUSSION: [MS] Flecainide [ME] and pharmacologically similar agents that interact with [MS] sodium [ME] channels may cause delirium in susceptible patients.

A MEDLINE search (1966-January 2009) revealed one in vivo pharmacokinetic study on the interaction between [MS] flecainide [ME], a CYP2D6 substrate, and [MS] paroxetine [ME], a CYP2D6 inhibitor, as well as 3 case reports of [MS] flecainide [ME]-induced delirium.

According to the Naranjo probability scale, [MS] flecainide [ME] was the probable cause of the patient's delirium; the Horn Drug Interaction Probability Scale indicates a possible pharmacokinetic drug interaction between [MS] flecainide [ME] and [MS] paroxetine [ME].
CONCLUSIONS: Supratherapeutic [MS] flecainide [ME] plasma concentrations may cause delirium.

Because toxicity may occur when [MS] flecainide [ME] is prescribed with [MS] paroxetine [ME] and other potent CYP2D6 inhibitors, [MS] flecainide [ME] plasma concentrations should be monitored closely with commencement of [MS] CYP2D6 [ME] inhibitors.
Depression, impulsiveness, sleep, and memory in past and present polydrug users of [MS] 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine [ME] ([MS] MDMA [ME], [MS] ecstasy [ME]).
RATIONALE: [MS] Ecstasy [ME] ([MS] 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine [ME], [MS] MDMA [ME]) is a worldwide recreational drug of abuse.
Unfortunately, the results from human research investigating its psychological effects have been inconsistent.

OBJECTIVES: The present study aimed to be the largest to date in sample size and [MS] 5HT [ME]-related behaviors; the first to compare present [MS] ecstasy [ME] users with past users after an abstinence of 4 or more years, and the first to include robust controls for other recreational substances.

METHODS: A sample of 997 participants (52 % male) was recruited to four control groups (non-drug (ND), [MS] alcohol [ME]/[MS] nicotine [ME] (AN), [MS] cannabis [ME]/[MS] alcohol [ME]/[MS] nicotine [ME] ([MS] CAN [ME]), non-[MS] ecstasy [ME] polydrug (PD)), and two [MS] ecstasy [ME] polydrug groups
(present ([MS] MDMA [ME]) and past users (EX-[MS] MDMA [ME]).

Participants completed a drug history questionnaire, Beck Depression Inventory, Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, and Wechsler Memory Scale-Revised which, in total, provided 13 psychometric measures.

RESULTS: While the CAN and PD groups tended to record greater deficits than the non-drug controls, the [MS] MDMA [ME] and EX-[MS] MDMA [ME] groups recorded greater deficits than all the control groups on ten of the 13 psychometric measures.
Strikingly, despite prolonged abstinence (mean, 4.98; range, 4-9 years), past [MS] ecstasy [ME] users showed few signs of recovery.
Compared with present [MS] ecstasy [ME] users, the past users showed no change for ten measures, increased impairment for two measures, and improvement on just one measure.

CONCLUSIONS: Given this record of impaired memory and clinically significant levels of depression, impulsiveness, and sleep disturbance, the prognosis for the current generation of [MS] ecstasy [ME] users is a major cause for concern.
A comparison of severe hemodynamic disturbances between [MS] dexmedetomidine [ME] and [MS] propofol [ME] for sedation in neurocritical care patients.
OBJECTIVE: [MS] Dexmedetomidine [ME] and [MS] propofol [ME] are commonly used sedatives in neurocritical care as they allow for frequent neurologic examinations.
However, both agents are associated with significant hemodynamic side effects.
The primary objective of this study is to compare the prevalence of severe hemodynamic effects in neurocritical care patients receiving [MS] dexmedetomidine [ME] and [MS] propofol [ME].
DESIGN: Multicenter, retrospective, propensity-matched cohort study.
SETTING: Neurocritical care units at two academic medical centers with dedicated neurocritical care teams and board-certified neurointensivists.
PATIENTS: Neurocritical care patients admitted between July 2009 and September 2012 were evaluated and then matched 1:1 based on propensity scoring of baseline characteristics.
INTERVENTIONS: Continuous sedation with [MS] dexmedetomidine [ME] or [MS] propofol [ME].

MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS: A total of 342 patients (105 [MS] dexmedetomidine [ME] and 237 [MS] propofol [ME]) were included in the analysis, with 190 matched (95 in each group) by propensity score.
The primary outcome of this study was a composite of severe hypotension (mean arterial pressure < 60 mm Hg) and bradycardia (heart rate < 50 beats/min) during sedative infusion.
No difference in the primary composite outcome in both the unmatched (30% vs 30%, p = 0.94) or matched cohorts (28% vs 34%, p = 0.35) could be found.
When analyzed separately, no differences could be found in the prevalence of severe hypotension or bradycardia in either the unmatched or matched cohorts.
CONCLUSIONS: Severe hypotension and bradycardia occur at similar prevalence in neurocritical care patients who receive [MS] dexmedetomidine [ME] or [MS] propofol [ME].
Providers should similarly consider the likelihood of hypotension or bradycardia before starting either sedative.
Effects of [MS] dehydroepiandrosterone [ME] in [MS] amphetamine [ME]-induced schizophrenia models in mice.
OBJECTIVE: To examine the effects of [MS] dehydroepiandrosterone [ME] ([MS] DHEA [ME]) on animal models of schizophrenia.
METHODS: Seventy Swiss albino female mice (25-35 g) were divided into 4 groups: [MS] amphetamine [ME]-free (control), [MS] amphetamine [ME], 50, and 100 mg/kg [MS] DHEA [ME].
The [MS] DHEA [ME] was administered intraperitoneally (ip) for 5 days.

[MS] Amphetamine [ME] (3 mg/kg ip) induced hyper locomotion, [MS] apomorphine [ME] (1.5 mg/kg subcutaneously [sc]) induced climbing, and [MS] haloperidol [ME] (1.5 mg/kg sc) induced catalepsy tests were used as animal models of schizophrenia.
The study was conducted at the Animal Experiment Laboratories, Department of Pharmacology, Medical School, Eskisehir Osmangazi University, Eskisehir, Turkey between March and May 2012.
Statistical analysis was carried out using Kruskal-Wallis test for hyper locomotion, and one-way ANOVA for climbing and catalepsy tests.
RESULTS: In the [MS] amphetamine [ME]-induced locomotion test, there were significant increases in all movements compared with the [MS] amphetamine [ME]-free group.
Both [MS] DHEA [ME] 50 mg/kg (p<0.05), and 100 mg/kg (p<0.01) significantly decreased all movements compared with the [MS] amphetamine [ME]-induced locomotion group.
There was a significant difference between groups in the [MS] haloperidol [ME]-induced catalepsy test (p<0.05).
There was no significant difference between groups in terms of total climbing time in the [MS] apomorphine [ME]-induced climbing test (p>0.05).
CONCLUSION: We observed that [MS] DHEA [ME] reduced locomotor activity and increased catalepsy at both doses, while it had no effect on climbing behavior.
We suggest that [MS] DHEA [ME] displays typical [MS] neuroleptic [ME]-like effects, and may be used in the treatment of schizophrenia.
[MS] Aconitine [ME]-induced [MS] Ca2+ [ME] overload causes arrhythmia and triggers apoptosis through p38 MAPK signaling pathway in rats.
[MS] Aconitine [ME] is a major bioactive [MS] diterpenoid alkaloid [ME] with high content derived from herbal aconitum plants.
Emerging evidence indicates that voltage-dependent Na(+) channels have pivotal roles in the cardiotoxicity of [MS] aconitine [ME].
However, no reports are available on the role of [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] in [MS] aconitine [ME] poisoning.
In this study, we explored the importance of pathological [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] signaling in [MS] aconitine [ME] poisoning in vitro and in vivo.
We found that [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] overload lead to accelerated beating rhythm in adult rat ventricular myocytes and caused arrhythmia in conscious freely moving rats.

To investigate effects of [MS] aconitine [ME] on myocardial injury, we performed cytotoxicity assay in neonatal rat ventricular myocytes (NRVMs), as well as measured lactate dehydrogenase level in the culture medium of NRVMs and activities of serum cardiac enzymes in rats.
The results showed that [MS] aconitine [ME] resulted in myocardial injury and reduced NRVMs viability dose-dependently.

To confirm the pro-apoptotic effects, we performed flow cytometric detection, cardiac histology, transmission electron microscopy and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated [MS] dUTP [ME]-[MS] biotin [ME] nick end labeling assay.
The results showed that [MS] aconitine [ME] stimulated apoptosis time-dependently.

The expression analysis of [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] handling proteins demonstrated that [MS] aconitine [ME] promoted [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] overload through the expression regulation of [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] handling proteins.
The expression analysis of apoptosis-related proteins revealed that pro-apoptotic protein expression was upregulated, and anti-apoptotic protein BCL-2 expression was downregulated.
Furthermore, increased phosphorylation of MAPK family members, especially the P-P38/P38 ratio was found in cardiac tissues.

Hence, our results suggest that [MS] aconitine [ME] significantly aggravates [MS] Ca(2+) [ME] overload and causes arrhythmia and finally promotes apoptotic development via phosphorylation of P38 mitogen-activated protein kinase.
